messageBody:
Yes, and I wonder about that a lot.. I think that when I was in school
there was this unspoken assumption that, well, to write code you have to
be smart and if you're smart you'll be able to keep the whole system in
your head anyway -- using tests as change detectors would be seen as a
sign of weakness. I guess it doesn't help either that it took a while to
make rapid builds possible also. We had to get past batch processing, etc.

Anyway, I hope that the encapsulation balance changes. I've been doing a
lot thinking on it recently and I'll be presenting a session called 'API
Design As If Unit Testing Mattered' at SDWest and SPA2007. It's really
all about the fact that it's obvious that most commercial API designers
haven't thought about how to make it possible to write unit tests for
code that uses their APIs. I'm going to show some glaring examples in
Java, C++, and C#, and talk about some alternatives.

Michael Feathers
www.objectmentor.com

Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>>The emphasis on testing has only received more visibility in the past
>>five years, and some of its principles are indeed at odds with some of
>>the OO knowledge that has been pervading the software industry for two
>>decades now.
>>
>>After being told repeatedly that encapsulation was paramount to
>>software quality, it's not always easy to let this go in favor of
>>another technique, but I think the message is getting through and that
>>more and more developers are becoming more aware of the pros and cons
>>between "extreme OO" and "pragmatic testing".
>>
>>In hindsight, I am absolutely shocked that all the teachers I had in
>>school 20+ years ago that I had so much respect for had absolutely no
>>inclination (and sometimes only contempt) for testing...
>>
>>
